docs.snippet: LEAD: NORMAN BROSTERMAN does not consider himself a toy collector. ''These things are much more than toys,'' he said, referring to the 265 sets of children's architectural building blocks that crowd the closets of his Upper West Side apartment. ''...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: NORMAN BROSTERMAN does not consider himself a toy collector. ''These things are much more than toys,'' he said, referring to the 265 sets of children's architectural building blocks that crowd the closets of his Upper West Side apartment. ''They represent the whole history of architecture. You have to wonder which architects played with which ones when they were kids.
